Dear Mr. McKeage,
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 For repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.

On November 29, 2021, a special investigation was initiated into the allegations
described above. Staff and youth were interviewed. A tour of the facility was
conducted twice. Various documents were reviewed. What follows is information
obtained from the aforementioned sources.
ALLEGATION:
It is alleged that youth are locked in their rooms after shower time until the next
morning.
INVESTIGATION:
On December 3, 2021, Staff 1, the agency Program Manager was informed on site
of the complaint and that an investigation had been initiated.
The complainant in this case is anonymous and therefore specifics about the
allegations were not obtained.
On December 3, 2021, and January 11, 2022, Staff 1 was interviewed. Staff 1 is a
working out of class program manager. Staff 1 reported that staffing shortages have
been problematic for the agency since summer 2021. Staff 1 informed me of the
evening schedule for youth which begins with youth taking showers at 6pm daily.
One youth at a time is allowed to take a shower while the rest of the youth are
locked in their rooms. Staff 1 reported that once showers begin not more than one
youth at a time are allowed outside of their rooms except to take a shower or to
receive medication. When showers are concluded youth who take medications
receive them at 7:30pm. Staff 1 reported that at 8:00 pm youth are secured in their
rooms for the evening until morning wake up at 8:00am. Staff 1 reported that prior to
staffing shortages youth who were doing well and had obtained a “transition status”
could be out of their rooms until 9:00pm, Sunday through Thursday, and until
9:30pm on Friday and Saturday nights. Staff 1 reported that this could be
accommodated when there was a 2:00pm to 10:00pm shift staff which, until recently,
did not exist for several months due to the staffing shortages. Staff 1 reported that at
8:00pm night staff arrive and work a 12 hour shift, until 8:00am the next morning.
Staff 1 reported that during the shift the night staff is responsible for supervision and
room checks of 2 pods, thus he/she cannot allow transition level youth out of their
rooms due to the inability to supervise the youth as well as conduct room checks.
Staff 1 reported that new staff are being hired which will resolve the staffing shortage
problem.
On January 11, 2022, Youth A was interviewed. Youth A is a 16 year old male.
Youth A reported that showers begin at 6:00pm, then medication time is after
showers. Youth A reported that medications are given to youth one at a time while
other youth are in their rooms. Youth A reported that showers are taken one at a
time while the rest of the youth are in their rooms. Youth A reported that at 8:00pm is
bedtime.
3

On January 11, 2022, Youth B was interviewed. Youth B is 16 year old male. Youth
B reported the same schedule as reported by Youth A. Youth B reported that when
there were fewer youth on the pod, after showers youth could be out in the milieu
after shower time but that hasn’t happened very often since the program is short
staffed.
On January 11, 2022, Youth C was interviewed. Youth C is a 15 year old female.
Youth C reported the same schedule as Youth A but added that sometimes
recreation would occur after dinner and before shower time when they had sufficient
staffing.
On January 11, 2022, Youth D was interviewed. Youth D is an 18 year old female.
Youth D reported that showers begin at 6:00pm and medications are passed at
7:30pm. Youth D reported that showers are taken one at a time with the other youth
secured in their rooms. Youth D reported that after showers youth cannot come out
of their rooms until 8:45am the next morning. Youth A reported that there is not
enough staff to allow for youth to have time in the milieu after showers. Youth D
reported that before there was staffing problems youth who were doing well in the
program could stay up in the milieu until 9:00 or 9:30pm but this has not occurred for
several months when the program became short staffed.
On January 14, 2022, the WOC Director was interviewed. The Director
acknowledged that that during the staffing shortage there were times when youth
would be in their rooms from shower time at 6:00pm to 8:00am the next morning.
The Director reported that a youth could attend a therapy visit in the evening or
complete a chore in the pod. The Director also acknowledged that transition youth
were not able to stay up in the milieu past 8:00pm due to staffing shortages. The
Director reported that additional staff have been hired and this weekend transition
youth will once again be allowed “late nights”. The Director reported that due to now
being at full staffing all youth will be allowed down time in the milieu before bedtime.
4

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4161 Seclusion rooms; policies and procedures.
An institution approved to use a seclusion room shall
establish and follow written policies and procedures
specifying its use. The policy shall include, at a minimum, all
of the following provisions:
(b) The room may only be used if a resident is in danger of
jeopardizing the safety and security of himself, herself, or
others.
ANALYSIS: The Program Manager and Youths A, B, C and D all stated that
due to staffing shortages there were times when youth were
secluded in their rooms from the 6:00pm shower time until the
next morning at 8:00am, except to take a shower or receive
medication. The Director acknowledged the same, adding
occasionally a youth would also come out of their room for a
choir or therapy. Staffing shortages is not an allowable reason
for the use of seclusion.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
It is alleged that agency staff are not conducting daytime room checks for youth
experiencing mental health problems.
INVESTIGATION:
During the interview with Staff 1 he reported that room checks on youth confined to
their bedroom for potential self-harm or behavioral issue are being checked by staff
on a variable basis not to exceed 15 minutes. Staff 1 reported that the room checks
are documented on a “room confinement log”. Staff 1 reported that supervisors
review room check logs for compliance. Staff 1 submitted room check logs for my
review.
DOCUMENT REVIEW:
Bay Pines Center Room Confinement Log: The complaint did not specify when or
for what youth room checks were not being completed therefore a sample of the logs
for October 2021, November 2021, and December 2021, were reviewed. The logs
document that room checks were occurring as required by the rule.
5

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio.
(1) The licensee shall develop and adhere to a written staff-to-
resident ratio formula for direct care workers.
4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the
direct supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable
interval, eye-on checks of residents. The time between the
variable interval checks shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
ANALYSIS: Staff 1 reported and documentation confirmed room checks
room checks were occurring according to the rule.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
It is alleged that changes in meal menus are not updated and posted.
INVESTIGATION:
On December 3, 2021, Staff 2 was interviewed. Staff reported that she was the cook
and still helps out in the kitchen occasionally. Staff 2 reports that since the advent of
COVID menus are changed frequently as Gordon Food Services does not always
have the requested food items and so substitutions occur frequently. Staff 2 reported
that she knew that changes to the menu need to be reflected on the menu. Staff 2
reported that she uses post-its and sticks them on the menu to reflect changes.
During the tour of the facility, I asked Staff 1 to show me where menus are posted.
Staff 1 showed me where the menu is to be posted and there was no menu posted.
Staff 1 and Staff 2 were asked where the menu was. Staff 1 and Staff 2 reported that
they did not know where the menu was or why one was not posted.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4149 Resident nutrition.
(4) Menus, including snacks if provided, shall be written
and posted prior to the serving of the meal. Any change or
substitution shall be noted and considered as part of the
original menu. Menus shall be retained for 1 year.
6

ANALYSIS: There was not a menu posted in the area Staff 1 reported it
should be posted. Staff 1 and Staff 2 could not account for a
menu or why it was not posted.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
It is alleged that toilets in youth bedrooms are not always working.
INVESTIGATION:
On December 3, 2021, and December 15, 2021, I conducted unannounced visits to
the agency. A tour of the facility was conducted each time. During the December 3,
2021, unannounced visit the functioning of the toilets of each unit pod was observed.
There were no concerns noted as toilets were flushing and in good operation. No
concerns were noted during the December 15, 2021, inspection.
On December 3, 2021, Staff 3, the facility maintenance person was interviewed.
Staff 3 reported that sometimes a toilet will get plugged as youth sometimes will try
to flush clothing or other items and the toilet will become plugged. Staff 3 reported
that a week prior to the interview a youth had flushed a towel and the toilet became
plugged. Staff 3 reported that the youth was moved to another room for the night,
and he unplugged the toilet the following day.
During the December 3, 2021, interview with Staff 1 he reported that toilets will
occasionally become plugged because youth will attempt to flush T-Shirts or other
items causing the toilet to become plugged. Staff 1 reported that when that happens
each pod has a community toilet that can be used until maintenance unplugs the
bedroom toilet.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4407 Facility and premises maintenance.
(6) Plumbing fixtures and water and waste pipes shall be
properly installed and maintained in good working
condition.
7

ANALYSIS: During the unannounced visits a sample of toilets in each pod
were flushed and all were operational. Staff 1 reported, as well
as Staff 2, that sometimes a toilet will become plugged and
maintenance is required to unplug it. Staff 1 reported that all
youth have access to community toilets should a youth’s
bedroom toilet become plugged.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
It is alleged that youth are not receiving therapy and the therapist encourages
relationships between male and female youth.
INVESTIGATION:
During a phone interview with the Director on January 11, 2021, I requested
documentation of therapy for a sample of 5 youth. The Director was asked if therapy
is being provided for youth and he acknowledged that during a loss of staff in
summer 2021, and until Staff 4 was contracted to provide therapy beginning in
November 2021, there was a lapse of therapeutic services. The Director reported
that one therapist was placed on administrative leave in September 2021 and
another therapist had left the agency in March 2021.
On January 11, 2021, Staff 4, a contracted therapist was interviewed via telephone.
Staff 4 reported that she conducts therapy weekly with youth. Staff 4 reported that
she began providing the service beginning in November 2021.
The Director and Staff 4 were asked if they have encouraged relationships between
youth in the program. The complaint was vague in that it did not specify or define
relationships or identify youth. They denied that this has occurred.
DOCUMENT REVIEW: Therapy notes were reviewed for 5 youth. Documentation of
therapy for Youth D indicates that therapy services were not provided for Youth D
from March 4, 2021, through October 17, 2021. Documentation of therapy for Youth
C indicates that therapy services were not provided for Youth C from September 29,
2021, to November 24, 2021. There was no documentation of therapy for Youth F
who was placed on June 17, 2021. Youth E and Youth G entered the program in
December 2021 and therapy services were provided weekly.
8

APPLICABLE RULE
JRM 302 Individual or Group Therapy
At least two times per week, direct therapeutic
interventions must be provided for each youth individually
and/or in group sessions. At least one session per week
must be an individual therapy session. Individual and/or
group therapy must be provided in accordance with the
youth's treatment needs as identified in the youth's
treatment plan.
ANALYSIS: The director acknowledged and documentation supports that
therapy was not provided to Youth C, Youth D, and Youth F for
extended periods of time when the agency was short staffed or
without therapists.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan the recommendation is for
continuance of the regular license.
January 14, 2022
